title: "Veigar Lacked Counter Play"
body:
It's getting really disturbing that this is a thing. I have never doubted that Veigar was in many ways poorly designed, but three seasons ago no one would have looked at the champ and thought themselves unable to find a way to beat him. His weaknesses were obvious. His power was deserved. He was inflexible and easily understood.

This isn't the case of champions like Nasus that grow out of control by other champions being nerfed too hard in comparison; Veigar can still be delayed. He can still be worked around. Each of you has plenty of opportunities to get a bountiful lead over him and, as someone who playes mages like Swain, Malzahar and Anivia, I'm not in any way threatened by his current state. 
 
It's not the changes that bug me. I don't particularly like them, as they seem half assed at being meaningful and seem to have been done more so for the sake of making a change, but I understand the reasoning. You can't put too much power in one basket, particularly when it's got a decent level of certainty to it. That's not the issue.

It's the community that's asking for coddling that's out of control. Three seasons ago seeing his bad early game and his lack of resilience against ganks would have been enough to give us something to work with. The group mentality has shifted to something much, much worse now. "If he lines up the stun perfectly and I don't have the edge, I still *shouldn't* be punished for it."

The essence of strategy is really dying here. Swiftly at that. This game is being pushed to become more and more shallow, and it seems like a large enough portion of the community is encouraging it.

replies.body:
This is an interesting issue. Personally I think this NEEDED to be done at some point (same with the mana regen changes that happened previously), the question remains did it have to happen now; when Veigar still has other issues.

I'd have just left him like he was for now, until his changes actually became a priority.

Malzahar ironically has the same issue Veigar does on live, once he has an advantage over you, theres nothing you can do to him (alone anyway), simply because no amount of skill allows you to outplay a point and click CC, that doesn't  (in my opinion) make them overpowered (not currently anyway, power is always relative to the strength of others), just badly designed

Edit: As an elaboration on the mana regen changes; I feel those should've been done after some of the problem assassins (or just manaless champs in general) were toned down (preventing the mana-regen nerfs from indirectly buffing them too much; by nerfing the mages that were significantly affected by those changes.)

Being a Veigar main I disagree that there is nothing you can do against a point and click cc champ who is really far ahead and I'll give you an example. When I play Veigar, once I get fed my main priority is to delete the most fed carry on the enemy team and then stay back contributing dmg as q w and e come off cooldown. I had one game where I was killing the enemy apc and adc over and over but end game i could not do anything because their really beefy braum was completely on my nuts and I couldn't nuke the important people down and even with 1100 ap it wasn't worth trying to nuke the braum down so we ended up losing. Similarly, I was playing Warwick one game and there was a massively fed Veigar on the enemy team (Had about 15 more kills than me) who at one point I rushed him, he did full combo, I qss'ed the stun and dodged the Dark Matter while taking Baleful Strike and Primordial Burst, and then I ulted him and killed him solo. Veigar is not hard to play against if your beef knows what they are doing.
Yes, his E is a better Thresh ult. It makes up for the fact that if you somehow avoid it, he has NOTHING. No dash, not speed boost, no blink, not even a slow. Nothing.

You can make the same argument for Viktor or Brand or Heimer and a ton of other immobile mages who rely on one delayed cc for safety and yet their cc isn't nearly as potent. Granted that's probably why they are played at the same level as Veigar. Still, I don't think anyone in the game has a skillshot that is so impossible to predict as Veigar's and that makes it incredibly frustrating to play against him. You can at best be lucky enough that he missed his stun so you can blink out of it.

Because Veigar's actually a burst mage... not a reset-burst assassin, not a burst-plus-spammable-follow-up mage - no, he's one of the few times Riot actually made burst work at the expense of sustained damage.  The other 3 you listed don't have that problem to the same extent though, like you said, they're pretty unpopular too so idk if comparing them against Veigar says much.

I agree it's frustrating (used to main Kennen, believe me - I know), but it was a specific niche that Veigar filled and one that could actually counter the current league of mobility.  The proposed change erodes all chance he had against mobility, which basically dumpsters him for the foreseeable future.  As it is now, he looks like a weaker version of Annie in all respects.

Every champion gives something for something else. The problem with Veigar is that while he's primarily single target, his range is too crappy for him to actually make use of that once it starts to matter. His stun is too potent to give him any mobility but his range is too short for him to reach the backline. Someone like LB does his job much better. Syndra's burst is also balanced by her short ult range, but at least Riot recognized that having some dps might make her useful if she can't reach the squishies. He's just badly designed.

Sure, but if you're weighing the rest of his kit around that stun, then the LAST thing you do is remove the stun.  That's what everyone's (rightfully) complaining about here.

I guess I agree that the design wasn't great from the start, but if Riot really wants to bark up that tree, I'd suggest they start by not designing something equally as bad with each new champ released.

Whoa whoa whoa...
"Removing" the stun? I think you've been misinformed, his stun is going to have a delay, but it's not going anywhere. That's some heavy kneejerk panic here when people think Veigar is losing his only cc.

What would you consider lacking in counterplay among Riot's recent designs? Because I think you'll notice that the amount of skillshots has increased dramatically and in fact silence got removed from several assassins precisely because it stripped the opponent of any chance to stop themselves from getting bursted.

A .75 second delay is paramount to removing it, at least for defensive purposes.
If you factor in human reaction time of about .25 seconds, it's raised to 1 second 
Most assassins can kill Veigar in that time period

I fully agree. Riot wasn't wrong in saying they can't just drop extra power on him without recourse, and he would definitely have to succumb to changes eventually, but the compounding weaknesses to make the player *feel* that they have more control over a confrontation they had control of since the game began wasn't a poignant change to make.

It's not bad to have little room to react to every little thing. Veigar's current play style still warrants it.

> The essence of strategy is really dying here. Swiftly at that. This game is being pushed to become more and more shallow, and it seems like a large enough portion of the community is encouraging it.

We all know what's going on here. Mobility Creep is the issue here. Its no longer about "ooo Veigar survived lane against leblanc mid and Lee Sin jungle and has 300 cs at 30 minutes. Wow he got really powerful and deserves every bit of it." It's more about "omg did you see that big LCS play, she dashed at the perfect time and  moved into the brush right when it was about to hit and then flashed! Wow. just wow so much counterplay". Macro game is dying rapidly in league and Veigar - along with Nasus - was the undisputed champ of scaling.

I remember a game long time ago: I was with friends and they picked LeBlanc, I was so naïve that I picked Veigar saying "don't worry, Veigar is designed to counter that kind of champions"... nope, that LeBlanc ruined my whole game and I could do nothing to stop her: she just abused her mobility once and another to take me down every time, and, if she somehow failed a combo, she just blinked back to safety as fast as she could (probably spamming WWWWWWWWWWWWWW until she wore down the stun) I don't know how all those dashes and blinks are supposedly to be "countereable" and "healthy for the game" but Veigar's semi-insta-stun isn't.

It's not that Veigar lacked counter-play, it's that his STUN lacked counterplay 

Veigar's counterplay is obvious, punch his punk-ass face in when he's weak.
And yet, counter play is a concept that is holistically achieved. This isn't like fiddle's 3 second fear. It still has a margin of error. That, along with Veigar's total weaknesses should be enough.

"Margin of Error?" It was an insta-stun. It is the only non-targeted CC in the game you literally cannot ever miss with if you understand how it works.

News flash: Don't put your mouse over the enemy champion, centering the cage on them, and hope they walk through it. Place the center of the cage to their left. The cage spawns with them INSIDE OF THE STUN WALL.

I am vaguely aware of the fact that you can place the wall on someone given that they give you the time to line it up.  I'm also aware that you can move in multiple directions and apply plenty of enough pressure as to not give him that opportunity.

I've flashed the instant before a fed Veigar put his wall on where I had been and killed him for it while playing Brand of all champions. That's far from necessary, but don't insinuate that no one can manage working around it. "Instant" is not the same thing as "guaranteed."

You seem to be having a hard time wrapping your head around this whole "instant" concept. Next thing you know you'll be defending targeted abilities by going "Well I mean you *can* miss if you don't get your mouse over them in time or if you click the wrong thing!"

I never said guaranteed. I said "You can't miss if you know what you're doing." You can dodge a skillshot. You can dodged a delayed action AoE. You can't dodge Veigar's E. He can *miss,* if he's terrible, but that's not counterplay as it's entirely out of your hands. You just have to move erratically and pray you're playing against someone with the reflexes of an arthritic old man with three shots of whiskey in him.

Your ability to force the miss is your counter play. You shouldn't feel entitled to every last ability being something that you get warning sirens for. Delays favor mobile champions, but players that have been playing immobile ones since the game's inception are used to thinking preemptively enough to not have an utter stroke once an instant comes out.

Veigar's stun is absolutely AMAZING, but it did not lack counter play. It just requires more mechanical skills / thinking. 

1) Veigar needs some time to "line up a perfect stun." No one will have a consistent perfect stun with instant smartcasting.
2) You should not LITERALLY aim to drop your stun on top of someone, you should drop it very slightly ahead of them. If you aim to drop on top of them, even slight margin of error will mean they completely walk away free, the risk is not worth. 
3) Point #2 gives you a chance to react, if you walk towards Veigar when you think he's gonna drop the stun, you will be safe from the stun (Still stuck inside the cage though) but now you have escape route (blinks, flash, etc) or a chance to fight him. 


There's also QSS, Mikaels, Morg shield, Cleanse, Banshee's Veil, etc. These are all ways to avoid the stun when you walk through the cage. If you avoid the initial stun through reflex or insight, then you have even more options. And you can also hourglass his R. 

And as someone mentioned, you can get a tank up in his face and make him decide whether to blow his burst on the tank or to save it for the carry. Before, this wasn't as big of a deal as you can burst almost anyone with DFG + Q + W + R + Ignite. But without DFG, you wouldn't be able to delete the tank.

*You cannot force the miss.*

I know this is a novel concept, but the dodging player really has no actual influence over whether the ability connects. None. Zero. Nil. Zilch. Nada. They can try and confuse the Veigar player so that in the time between their key is pressed and the time the game registers it they are someone else, but if the only counterplay for an ability is lag and the player having an aneurism, *there is no counterplay.*

I really don't see how anyone who knows anything about this game can pretend like Veigar's stun has counterplay or that there's anything resembling a mind game in it. It's a stun that appears the second you press a button. Avoiding or missing it is a matter of luck, nothing else.

Well, I suppose this is a safe time for me to share some of the things that, when playing Veigar, I'm always afraid the other team will do to counter me.

1. Don't beat him in lane: **CRUSH** him in lane. He's not trying to beat you in lane: he's trying to survive, and if he can even just survive, he's got a shot. (Also, now he hates you passionately, and will not hesitate to obliterate you once the tables are turned.) One of the dumbest moves I've seen against me when playing Veigar is an enemy mid who decides to just passively farm. As Veigar, I am DELIGHTED to have a passive farm-lane with you. No, you need to crush him. His mana costs are huge. He's squishy. If he throws his stun in lane, he is lunch for a jungler. Gank him. Watch his mana bar. When it's low, beat the fluff out of him.
2. Don't get cocky if you beat him in lane. Even if you trounce him in lane, that's no reason to think you're the next Froggen and start fantasizing about going 30/0 this match. The worst thing you can do is get full of yourself and go hardcore glass cannon in search of pentakills. If you pour all that gold you got from him into purely offensive stats, you had better be good, because he will mercilessly punish you if you get out of position. Instead, you should get a little tanky. Tankiness is extremely strong against a Champion like Veigar: if his burst destroys you in one shot, he gets to giggle. If his burst takes you to 5% health, you can beat him to death with his own hat.
3. Positioning. "Waaa, there's no counterplay to his stun, I can't use dashes to jump around and avoid it like I was playing some kind of demented DDR game." The counterplay isn't about bouncing around the map with your fifteen dashes, KALISTA. [(How I loathe you.)](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/memes/ELnNVduE-kalista-comics-volume-i) It's about slower, subtler, less-twitchy counterplay. Are you rushing to the front of the pack to try to get a super-awesome initiation? Well, you'd better know where Veigar is. If not, let your frontline do their job. If Veigar gets greedy and just makes a beeline for you, he will get 100-0'd himself very, very quickly by your frontline, and they won't even have to blow an ult to do it.
4. It's not all about the 100-0. Everyone obsesses about his 100-0 single-target potential. When Veigar has been played at the pro level, do you know what the announcers talked about? Not his burst, but his stun. From a pro perspective, his stun is his greatest strength. Burst? Whatever. Vayne can burst you with her stupid crits. Darius can burst you with his axe, and then do the same to the rest of your team. Veigars who win games use their stuns (and those meteors, which HURT) to break the enemy team. Bursting a squishy mage or ADC is frosting on the cupcake. If you are a squishy, and the Veigar is good, you are not his primary target: you are a target of opportunity. If he catches you out, he'll destroy you, but if he chases obsessively after you, he'll get killed himself. He's thinking about how to use his stun to win the fight.
5. Bait his stun. Being Veigar means being very, very scared of the enemy team. Every one of them can delete you. Your stun is your protection. It's easy to freak out and throw it prematurely to save yourself. If you can scare him into throwing a misplaced stun, you only have to wait for it to disappear before your team is ready to counter-initiate hard. Once the battle-lines close, a Veigar without his stun available is an easy lunch for any halfway-durable bruiser or dash-y assassin. He can't waddle away from Zed or Akali, and odds are good he won't even be able to push "R" before he's stunlocked and killed. Once his stun is down, you should be seeing red.

So, just some thoughts.
